prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: [CII] in SSA22a C16
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: This SG is for observing [CII]157 in SSA22a C16 at z=3.0675.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
The primary purpose of this Science Goal is detecting the [CII]157 emission (rest-frame wavelength and frequency: 157.74 micron and 1900.5369 GHz) in a Lyman-break galaxy (LBG), SSA22a C16, at z_opt = 3.0675 (Troncoso et al. 2013, arXiv:1311.4576). For this redshift, the observed-frame wavelength and frequency are 641.61 micron and 467.2494 GHz, respectively. This corresponds to a wavelength where the atmospheric transmission is relatively good in the Band 8, and thus we select this frequency as a center of Baseband-1 ("representative frequency"). Since we assume that the velocity width of the [CII]157 emission to be 200 km/s (this is typical for LBGs; see Fig.5 in Carilli & Walter 2013, ARA&A, 51, 105), we select a bandwidth of 1875 MHz (1200 km/s, that corresponds to the widest velocity coverage). This wide bandwidth is needed to determine the continuum level accurately around a relatively broad emission line. The remaining 3 basebands are used to detect the continuum emission. Since a wider-coverage setting is preferred for detecting the continuum emission, we select a bandwidth of 1875 MHz also for these 3 basebands. We set the frequency separation between Baseband-1 and Baseband-2 to be 1.6 GHz, for covering the continuum emission continuously without a gap between 2 basebands (and the same separation is adopted also between Baseband-3 and Baseband-4). For reducing the data rate of this science goal, we adopt 8 channel binning for Baseband-1 ([CII]157) and 16 channel binning for the remaining 3 basebands (continuum). This results in the data rate of 1.7 MB/sec, that is below the "expected average data rate" (6 MB/sec). Note that this velocity binning does not affect our scientific analysis at all, because the resulting velocity resolution in Baseband-1 (~2.5 km/s, after the 8 channel binning) is much finer than any velocity structures expected for sub-millimeter spectra of star-forming galaxies.
The star-formation rate (SFR) of this object is 380 Msun/year (Troncoso et al. 2013). We adopt the relation of Kennicutt (1998, ARA&A, 36, 189) to convert SFR to L_FIR, and then adopt log(L_[CII]/L_FIR) = -2.5. This luminosity ratio is typical for non-IR-selected (less FIR-lumionus) galaxies (see, e.g., Fig.6 in Carilli & Walter 2013). Consequently, the suggested [CII]157 flux is 3.15 x 10^-16 erg/s/cm^2. This corresponds to 110 mJy, assuming the velocity width of 200 km/s. In order to detect this [CII]157 emission with S/N = 10, the required sensitivity is 11.0 mJy (rms). By adopting a 20 km/s velocity width for the time estimate (this width is needed to trace the velocity structure of [CII]157 in this source securely), the required observing time is 2.0 min (on-source), that corresponds to 28.2 min including calibrations and overheads. Although the on-source exposure time is short and the overhead fraction is large in this Science Goal, this is needed to achieve our scientific goal by combining all of the 6 SGs included in this program.
In the above feasibility calculation, we assume that the target is unresolved. The desired angular resolution for this Science Goal is 0.65 arcsec, that corresponds to the typical PSF size in our previous VLT/SINFONI observation for the target (Troncoso et al. 2013). We will try to compare the [CII]157 morphology with the maps of optical emission-line flux ratios, extinction, and metallicity. Since the expected maximum spatial extent of the [CII]157 emission in this source is ~2 arcsec, we do not use the ACA. No scheduling time constraints for this Science Goal.

Since a wider-coverage setting is preferred for detecting the continuum emission, we select a bandwidth of 1875 MHz also for these 3 basebands. We set the frequency separation between Baseband-1 and Baseband-2 to be 1.6 GHz, for covering the continuum emission continuously without a gap between 2 basebands (and the same separation is adopted also between Baseband-3 and Baseband-4). For reducing the data rate of this science goal, we adopt 8 channel binning for Baseband-1 ([CII]157) and 16 channel binning for the remaining 3 basebands (continuum). This results in the data rate of 1.7 MB/sec, that is below the "expected average data rate" (6 MB/sec). Note that this velocity binning does not affect our scientific analysis at all, because the resulting velocity resolution (~2.5 km/s, after the 8 channel binning) is much finer than any velocity structures expected for sub-millimeter spectra of star-forming galaxies.

Note that this flux is magnified one (that should be used for the observational feasibility study). This corresponds to 360 mJy, assuming the velocity width of 200 km/s. Since the expected maximum spatial extent of the [CII]157 emission in this source is ~3.0 arcsec, we do not use the ACA. No Scheduling time constraints for this Science Goal.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: [NII] in SSA22a C16
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: This SG is for observing [NII]205 in SSA22a C16 at z=3.0675.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
The primary purpose of this Science Goal is detecting the [NII]205 emission (rest-frame wavelength and frequency: 205.18 micron and 1461.1314 GHz) in a Lyman-break galaxy (LBG), SSA22a C16, at z_opt = 3.0675 (Troncoso et al. 2013, arXiv:1311.4576). For this redshift, the observed-frame wavelength and frequency are 834.57 micron and 359.2210 GHz, respectively. This corresponds to a wavelength where the atmospheric transmission is relatively good in the Band 7, and thus we select this frequency as a center of Baseband-1 ("representative frequency"). Since we assume that the velocity width of the [NII]205 emission to be 200 km/s (this is typical for [CII]157 in LBGs; see Fig.5 in Carilli & Walter 2013, ARA&A, 51, 105; and we assume that the velocity width is similar between [CII]157 and [NII]205), we select a bandwidth of 1875 MHz (1600 km/s, that corresponds to the widest velocity coverage). This wide bandwidth is needed to determine the continuum level accurately around a relatively broad emission line. The remaining 3 basebands are used to detect the continuum emission. Since a wider-coverage setting is preferred for detecting the continuum emission, we select a bandwidth of 1875 MHz also for these 3 basebands. The frequency center of Baseband-2 is selected to cover the H16_alpha recombination line, but we do not necessarily need to detect this line (since the main purpose of Baseband-2 is the continuum detection) and thus we do not discuss the observational feasibility for this line. We set the frequency separation between Baseband-3 and Baseband-4 to be 1.6 GHz, for covering the continuum emission continuously without a gap between 2 basebands. For reducing the data rate of this science goal, we adopt 8 channel binning for Baseband-1 ([NII]205) and 16 channel binning for the remaining 3 baseboards (continuum). This results in the data rate of 1.7 MB/sec, that is below the "expected average data rate" (6 MB/sec). Note that this velocity binning does not affect our scientific analysis at all, because the resulting velocity resolution (~3.3 km/s, after the 8 channel binning) is much finer than any velocity structures expected for sub-millimeter spectra of star-forming galaxies.
The expected [CII]157 flux of this object is 3.15 x 10^-16 erg/s/cm^2 (see the Science Goal for [CII]157 in this source). The expected [NII]205/[CII]157 flux ratio is in the range of 0.02-0.1 (Nagao et al. 2012, A&A, 542, L34). Consequently, the suggested [NII]205 flux is 1.58 x 10^-17 erg/s/cm^2 in the conservative case ([NII]205/[CII]157 = 0.02). This corresponds to 2.2 mJy, assuming the velocity width of 200 km/s. In order to detect this [NII]205 emission with S/N = 5, the required sensitivity is 0.44 mJy (rms). By adopting a 60 km/s velocity width for the time estimate, the required observing time is 32.7 min (on-source), that corresponds to 75.0 min including overheads.
In the above feasibility calculation, we assume that the target is unresolved. The desired angular resolution for this Science Goal is 0.65 arcsec, that corresponds to the typical PSF size in our previous VLT/SINFONI observation for the target (Troncoso et al. 2013). We will try to compare the [NII]205 morphology with the maps of optical emission-line flux ratios, extinction, and metallicity. Since the expected maximum spatial extent of the [NII]205 emission in this source is ~2 arcsec, we do not use the ACA. No scheduling time constraints for this Science Goal.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: Measuring the metallicity of galaxies at various redshifts is fundamental to investigate the physical process regulating the chemical evolution of galaxies. So far the metallicity of galaxies has been measured up to z~3.8; however, the conventional metallicity diagnostics exploit rest-frame optical emission lines, which prevent us from measuring the metallicity beyond z=4 due to the limited NIR atmospheric window. A more serious problem in the conventional methods is that they cannot be applied to heavily-obscured dusty young galaxies, that are the crucial population to study the galaxy evolution. To overcome these problems, we have developed a new metallicity indicator that consists of FIR fine-structure lines, the flux ratio of [NII]205/[CII]157. In Cycle 0, we have shown that this ratio is fairly high in a galaxy at z=4.8, suggesting that massive galaxies experienced their major chemical enrichment at very high-z. Here we propose to calibrate this indicator by observing this ratio for z~3 galaxies, whose metallicity has been measured also by conventional methods. Once we calibrate this FIR metallicity indicator, we will establish the new way for metallicity studies beyond z=4.
